production.title: Production
production.content: There is no detailed data on plastic production in {{country}}. The trade profile indicates a midstream manufacturing economy: {{country}} imports primary polymers and resins and converts them into packaging, films, footwear, and selected rubber products for domestic consumption and regional export.

trade.title: Trade
keyTrends: {{country}} is a net importer of plastics, with imports consistently and substantially exceeding exports between 2017 and 2022, reflecting high domestic demand for plastic materials and products and limited upstream polymer production capacity.

The trade profile indicates a midstream manufacturing economy, as {{country}} imports primary polymers and resins and converts them into packaging, films, footwear, and selected rubber products for domestic consumption and regional export.
A sharp contraction in plastic consumption occurred in 2020, likely due to the COVID-19 pandemic, followed by a strong rebound, highlighting the plastics sector’s high sensitivity to economic cycles.
The trade structure suggests dependence on Asian and regional supply chains for upstream polymer inputs, with predominantly regional integration for downstream manufactured exports.
trade.summaryLeft:
Plastic Imports

A total of 10,871 million USD worth of plastic was imported to {{country}} between 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, the total imports reached value of 2,456 million USD, of which:

  • ~ 44% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 13% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 13% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 31% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 0% was plastic waste.

The plastic imports included estimated 344 million USD of plastic packaging imports with notoriously short product lifetime.

Plastic exports

A total of 1,556 million USD worth of plastic was exported from {{country}} in the year(s) 2017-2022. In the latest reporting year 2022, exports reached a value of USD 387 million, of which:

  • ~ 22% was plastic in primary forms
  • ~ 25% was plastic in intermediate forms
  • ~ 3% was intermediate manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 50% was final manufactured plastic goods
  • ~ 1% was plastic waste.

Plastic exports included estimated 58 million USD of plastic packaging.
trade.summary:
Plastic trade trends

Between years 2017 and 2022, the amount of plastic imported to {{country}} has increased by 56.5%, while the amount of plastic exported from {{country}} has increased by 103.3%.

Despite faster export growth in percentage terms, imports remain significantly larger in absolute value. In 2022, imports totalled approximately USD 2,456 million, compared with exports of roughly USD 387 million, resulting in a persistent trade deficit.

Primary plastics accounted for the largest share of imports, peaking at USD 1,082 million in 2022. This reflects {{country}}’s reliance on primary polymers to supply domestic converters. Although {{country}} exports some primary plastics, volumes remain modest, increasing from USD 14 million in 2017 to USD 83 million in 2022.

Exports are concentrated in processed and final manufactured goods. Final plastic products are consistently the largest export category, reaching USD 193 million in 2022. However, this remains far below imports of final goods, which reached USD 750 million in the same year. This indicates domestic value addition but insufficient scale to meet national demand.

A sharp contraction across all categories occurred in 2020, consistent with the pandemic-related disruptions to industrial production and trade. The subsequent surge in imports and exports in 2021–2022 reflects economic recovery and renewed demand in plastic-related sectors. The plastic waste trade has generally declined over the long term, with temporary increases in waste exports observed in 2021.
trade.tradingPartners:
Asia is {{country}}’s largest supplier of plastics, accounting for roughly half of total imports, followed closely by trading partners in the Americas. Europe plays a smaller but significant role, whereas Africa and Oceania account for less than 1% of total trade flows.

Most plastic exports are directed to the Americas, indicating that {{country}}’s plastics industry competes primarily in neighbouring and regional markets rather than globally diversified destinations.
trade.productCategories: The World Trade Organisation’s database provides additional insight into the structure of {{country}}’s plastics economy. Here, we focus on the trade categories for plastics, synthetic textiles, and rubber. Imports are dominated by plastics and articles thereof (HS Chapter 39), particularly polymers and resins in primary form, including ethylene and propylene polymers. This confirms limited upstream petrochemical production and strong reliance on imported virgin resins to supply domestic manufacturing. Exports under HS Chapter 39 are concentrated in plastic sheets, films, and packaging materials. This indicates the presence of a functioning midstream plastics-conversion industry focused on extrusion and packaging. Textiles, apparel and footwear (HS chapters 54-65), represent the second most significant trade category. Imports include plastic-based footwear and synthetic filament fabrics, while exports include waterproof footwear, sacks and bags for packing goods. This demonstrates value addition through polymer-to-product conversion in both consumer and industrial goods. The rubber (HS Chapter 40) trade is dominated by new pneumatic tyres on both the import and export sides. This suggests some domestic tyre manufacturing or assembly capacity, though production does not meet domestic demand.

consumption.title: Consumption
consumption.content:
Plastic consumption is calculated as total imports minus exports, using UNCTAD data. This measure of apparent consumption indicates that {{country}} is a net importer of plastics.

Between 2017 and 2019, apparent consumption remained relatively stable at around USD 1,400–1,600 million annually. In 2020, consumption declined sharply due to pandemic-related economic contraction. However, a strong rebound occurred in 2021, with consumption increasing by approximately 59%, followed by a peak of over USD 2,000 million in 2022.

wasteManagement.title: Waste Management
keyTrends: {{country}} generated approximately 627 thousand tonnes of plastic waste in 2022, with waste generation concentrated in urban areas (418 thousand tonnes, 67%) compared to rural areas (209 thousand tonnes, 33%).

Collection coverage is relatively high (87–89%, 545 thousand tonnes collected in 2022) and formal (79%, 497 thousand tonnes), but 13% remains uncollected (82 thousand tonnes), representing a persistent and significant source of leakage.
Recycling capture is modest, with 13% collected for recycling (81 thousand tonnes), highlighting a substantial gap between collection and material recovery.
The municipal plastic waste stream is dominated by flexible (39%) and rigid (35%), with PET bottles at 16% and multilayer at 4%.
52% (326,000 tonnes) was landfilled, while 18% (113,000 tonnes) went to dumpsites, and 16% (100,000 tonnes) openly burned, indicating continued reliance on disposal rather than recovery.
wasteManagement.content:
Plastic waste from municipal solid waste

An estimated 5,323 thousand tonnes of municipal solid waste were generated in {{country}} in 2020, with an estimated 0.83kg of MSW per person per day. An estimated 11% of municipal solid waste is plastic, implying a plastic waste generation of 585,530 tonnes. Another study suggested that {{country}} generated approximately 627,000 tonnes of plastic waste in 2022, with waste generation concentrated in urban areas (418,000 tonnes, 67%) compared to rural areas (209,000 tonnes, 33%). On the other hand, modelled trade data suggests that approximately 274,000 tonnes of packaging waste and 101,000 tonnes of textile waste were produced in 2021.

A study on global waste management modeling showed 89% of municipal solid waste is collection coverage. This is backed by another study which shows that the majority of plastic waste is collected and delivered through the formal waste management system (87–89%, 545,000 tonnes collected in 2022), but the informal sector remains high (8%, 48,000 tonnes in 2022), and 13% remains uncollected (82,000 tonnes). The majority of waste is sent to landfill (52%, 326,000 tonnes), with around 18% (113,000 tonnes) disposed of in dumpsites and 16% (100,000 tonnes) openly burned, indicating continued reliance on uncontrolled or semi-controlled disposal facilities.

Despite relatively strong collection coverage, available data suggest that only a small share of plastic waste is effectively recycled: approximately 13% (81,000 tonnes) of collected plastic waste is recycled. Only 2% (11,000 tonnes) was recycled in closed-loop systems, with an additional 6% (37,000 tonnes) recycled through open-cycle processes, highlighting limited material circularity.

The annual plastic emission including both debris and open burning is 88,460 tonnes per year, which is equivalent to 5 kg/person/year.

The estimated MSW generation per capita in {{country}} in 2020 was 0.83 kg per person per day.
wasteManagement.contentRight:
Plastic waste from non-municipal solid waste

Data on plastic waste from non-municipal sources, such as industrial, agricultural, construction, and commercial activities, are limited. However, sectoral estimates suggest that packaging, textiles, construction materials, and automotive-related plastics contribute significantly to total waste generation.

environment.title: Plastics in the Environment
keyTrends: Approximately 24,000 tonnes of plastic waste (4%) leaked to terrestrial and 16,000 tonnes (3%) entered water bodies.
environment.content:
Beach litter

The national average count of plastic beach litter items in {{country}} was 740,644 items per km² in 2018.

Common plastic items in the environment

{{country}}’s municipal plastic waste stream is dominated by flexible plastics (39%), followed by rigid plastics (35%), and PET bottles (16%), with a smaller share of multilayer materials (4%). Flexible packaging, including films, bags, and wrappers, are particularly prone to leakage due to its low weight and limited recycling value. Rigid containers and PET bottles are more likely to be collected, though recovery rates remain modest.

The prevalence of low-value flexible plastics and multilayer materials in the waste stream presents ongoing challenges for recycling systems and contributes disproportionately to environmental dispersion.
